title.narrative: Samadi Community Development Programme in India

description.narrative: The Community Development Program continues to provide communities with resources to address a wide range of community development needs. The CDP program works with 13 villages in Barikul, 13 in Samadi and 12 in Balughart. Each program initiative promotes self-sustaining, long-term economic development and improved community health. The program works with small, marginalized farmers to improve their knowledge of water harvesting techniques to improve crop yield. Artificial insemination improves the quality of livestock available to the farming communities. Coaching centers, run by the villagers, promote preservation of the local tribal language, Alchiki, and the importance of primary education for girls and boys. Youth are supported with technical education to promote small micro-businesses, further diversifying the income sources in the community. Ongoing women's cooperatives are strengthened by providing needed equipment, additional micro-loan capital, and skills training. Women's empowerment lies at the heart of many program activities, including previous support for an all-female team of community health volunteers who work with women and children in the villages to ensure safe deliveries, monitor child health and nutrition, and spread positive messages about disease prevention including HIV/AIDS. The health volunteers are backed up by the services of the clinic, which will continue to provide needed services in an area with limited access to medical facilities. These activities continue this year through sustained support. In previous years the program also addressed the lack of proper sanitation in the villages through latrine construction, reduced water borne diseases, reduced the use of open fields, and improved the village environment. A program evaluation was conducted in 2014 to review the past activities, and determine an exit strategy based on the learnings. In late 2014, the diocese proposed a 3 year strategy of empowering communities to build on their experiences and strengths to sustain all activities for the long term. In 2016, the program continues to train and equip community leaders in building up cooperatives and community-led networks, connecting with government mechanisms for additional resources, and directing support towards targeted interventions with the aim to inspire community members to become active in changing their own lives and in securing their rights.

Workshop on rights-based approaches to assist with the diversification of funding and sustainability of the activities following the end of Episcopal Relief & Development's partnership in December 2016, Collecting and disseminating information to mobilize available resources for the longer term community-based management of all programmatic activities, Conduct risk assessments in the 3 clusters of villages, Develop DRR committees in each village cluster to serve 17,400 persons, Facilitate 6 skills training workshops to 600 female participants, Constructing training centers & storage rooms for the 2 Tribal Women's Federation, Provision of training on livestock health and vaccination management to 300 farmers, Build 6 rain water harvesting structures for agricultural use to serve 800 farmers
